Award.AwardTitle: RI: Small: Integrating Learning and Search for Structured Prediction

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The field of machine learning is extremely successful in solving classification problems where the inputs are fixed size feature vectors and the outputs are a small fixed number of classes. However, many applications such as natural language understanding and visual scene interpretation involve inputs and outputs of variable size that have rich internal structure. This project will study new approaches for such structured prediction problems. For example, the inputs may be natural language documents or visual scenes and the outputs may be formal representations of their semantic content, such as entities inferred or observed and the relationships between them. Most approaches to structured prediction learn a cost function to score potential structured outputs. Finding the correct output for the given structured input then consists of inferring the least cost output. Unfortunately, the computational cost of this inference is prohibitive for expressive cost functions; this forces the use of either simpler cost functions or approximate inference. In either case, prediction accuracy can suffer.

The current project aims to address this issue by integrating learning and search in a new framework that allows for the development of novel algorithms for structured prediction. In particular, this project will address three topics: (1) A generic framework will be developed for cost function learning by imitating the decisions of an optimal time-bounded search procedure on the training data. This will allow for a wide range of state-of-the-art search algorithms to be leveraged for structured prediction. (2) A theory and framework will be developed to learn to speed up the search for a global optimum by compressing the search into a shorter time-frame. This will allow for learning to address not only accuracy but also the computational efficiency of the predictor. (3) Both the cost function learning and speedup learning will be instantiated in multiple search algorithms and evaluated in different applications.

The project seeks to make contributions to a variety of applications of broad impact including natural language understanding, tracking objects in video, and personalized scheduling. The frameworks, algorithms and testbeds for learning to search and structured prediction will be integrated into the Weka tool-box so that they can be easily combined with different supervised learning algorithms and used in further research. The results and benchmark domains will be publicly distributed through the project's web pages. A special topics graduate course will be taught on the topic of this proposal at Oregon State University.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of the project is to integrate machine learning and search for solving structured prediction tasks such as natural language processing, computer vision,  and automated planning.  We designed and implemented several algorithms for structured prediction and obtained state of the art results in tasks ranging from coreference resolution in natural language to video tracking in computer vision.  Here are some of the highlights of our work.

HC Search: In an award winning paper, we developed a new serach-based structured prediction approach called HC-search that combined limited discrepency search and linear function learning, and  improved upon previous search-based structured prediction approaches such as conditional random fields and support vector machines. We obtained state of the art performance in several domains such as hand writing recognition, scene labelling, and stress and phoneme prediction in speech. HC-Search framework was extended and applied to several other tasks such as multi-label learning in classification, coreference resolution in natural language processing, and biological image segmentation and labeling in computer vision.

Monte-Carlo Tree Search: We implemented a learning algorithm for speeding up the Monte-Carlo Tree Search algorithm  via action pruning. The algorithm learns from experience aquired from expensive searches and generates a ranking function over actions that allows for ordering and selective pruning. We showed that the addition of the learned knowledge significantly improves the anytime performance profile compared to using no knowledge and several naive baseline learning algorithms.

Computer Vision: The main problem in applying structured prediction to computer vision is that the search space at the pixel level is too huge and intractable. However, there are significant structural constraints such as contiguity of object and depth labels. We developed new ways of exploiting these structural constraints using new search operators that segment the image into contiguous regions. The granularity of the segments can be controlled by a threshold parameter which is explored by the search. Combining this search operator with data aggregation allowed the learner to learn from its own mistakes and yielded state of the art performance in three challenging tasks: object recognition, scene labelling and monecular depth estimation.

Object Tracking in Video: We formulate the problem of object  tracking in video as labeling mid-level features by object identifiers. We develop a new approach called constrained sequential laebling (CSL) that uses a cost function to sequentially assign labels while respecting the hard constraints computed via constraint propagation.  We also develop ways to learn constraints and give provably correct learning algorithms for cost functions whose performance improves with the strength of the constraints. Our experimental results show that CSL outperforms the state-of-the-art on challenging real world videos of volleyball, basketball and crowded pedestrian scenes.

Natural Language Processing: We developed a new framework for search-based multi-task structured prediction (MTSP) and achieved state of the art performance in 3 tasks in natural language processing, namely, named entity recognition, coreference resolution, and entity linking. We developed a cyclic search architectures to multi-task structured prediction that allows solving multiple tasks one after another in a cyclic fashion, that takes advantage of inter-task dependencies while keeping the search efficient.

Planning in Hybrid MDPs:  Hybrid (mixed discrete and continuous) state and action Markov Decision Processes (HSA-MDPs) provide an expressive formalism for modeling stochastic and concurrent sequential decision-making problems. We developed a domain-independent approach for planning in HSA-MDPs based on the framework of hindsight optimization (HOP) by reducing it to Mixed Integre Linear Programs (MILPs).  Our approach was the first to successfully scale to medium-sized HSA-MDPs in domains such as inventory control, reservoir control, and emergency response.
